I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity  investment  in  the  Asia  Water  Fund  up  to  $20  million.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  Economic and Sector Background 
2.  Only 2.5% of the total global water supply is fresh water. Almost 70% of that amount is 
permanently frozen in glaciers and ice caps, leaving readily available surface water at less than 
1% of the world’s water volume. Asia, with 60% of the world’s population, only has access to 
40%1 of that amount, with about 670 million people in the region in 2002 lacking access to 
potable water (about one in five people). 2 With unceasing and growing global demand for clean 
water—which the World Bank estimates will double every 20 years, in large part driven by 
population and economic growth, urbanization, and climate changes in Asia—the need for water 
infrastructure investments is critical.   
 
3.  Population  growth. Rapid population growth in Asia and the Pacific over the past 
decade has led to increasing demand for water and sanitation services. According to the UN 
Secretariat’s database, the population in Asia rose from around 3.7 billion in 2000 to 4.2 billion 
in  2008—an  increase  of  about  500  million  or  13.5%—and  it  is  expected  to  increase  by 
400 million by 2020, nearly a 24% increase from the 2000 level.3 This trend shows the need for 
Asia to accelerate its efforts on water infrastructure development to satisfy the requirement of 
the projected population in the decades to come. 
 
4.  Economic growth and urbanization. Asia and the Pacific have enjoyed remarkable 
economic growth in the last decade. For example, according to the National Bureau of Statistics 
of China (NBSC), the urbanization rate in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) was 43.9% in 
2007 and is predicted to be about 60%–65% by 2030. However, sanitation and wastewater 
treatment facilities have not kept pace with the rapid development. The NBSC states that the 
sewage treatment rate in the PRC was only 48.4% in 2005, which is significantly lower than the 
rate of developed economies. To maintain Asia’s current and future economic growth rate, new 
water infrastructure investments and revamping existing water infrastructure are paramount.  
 
5.  Pollution  and  climate  changes.  The  Intergovernmental  Panel  on  Climate  Change 
(IPCC) states that 11 of the 12 years to 2006 were the warmest since 1850 in terms of global 
surface temperature.4 One of the worst effects of this climate change is the occurrence of 
extreme weather events and their impact on water, and incidences of flooding that damage both 
natural sources of and  infrastructure for potable water in Asia and the Pacific. The sea level rise 
as a result of the melting of glaciers and ice caps in the northern and southern hemispheres has 
led to the intrusion of salt water to fresh water aquifers and consequently exacerbated fresh 
water scarcity for the large population in Asia. 
 
6.  Opportunity for private sector investments.  The overwhelming amount of investment 
required to meet the growing demand for water supply and sanitation in Asia, at a time when

fiscal policies are strained by stimulus packages meant to counter the effects of the global 
financial crisis, will make it difficult for public sector in the the developing world to continue to 
support capital-intensive projects in the water sector in its own. The private sector will have to 
play a key role in creating and maintaining water infrastructure during the decades to come.  
 
7.  To that end, as an independent investment vehicle comprising third-party capital, the 
fund is targeting a financial engineering niche in the water infrastructure sector in which project 
engineering companies are selected based on skill level as opposed to a conventional business 
model in which engineering companies are selected based on ability and willingness to invest 
their equity in a project.  With this model, the fund expects to generate superior investment 
returns and greater private sector participation.  This initiative is bolstered by water sector 
regulation, which has been moving toward full cost recovery policies in Asia and the Pacific, with 
willingness to reduce surface water pollution leading to tariff increases. Pricing water services in 
this manner encourages water conservation, as well as yield returns that justify investing in 
water sector infrastructure. Private water investments, incorporating the objectives of helping to 
alleviate Asia’s impending water crisis while making a sustainable return to investors, create a 
win-win solution for all stakeholders. 
 
B.   Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 
8.  The  fund  is  being  established  to  make  private  equity  investments  in  water  and 
wastewater assets in certain ADB DMCs. As such, it is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2020,5 
which seeks to safeguard the environment and reduce the severe strain pollution is putting on 
the region’s land, forests, water systems, wetlands, marine ecosystems, and other natural 
resources  upon  which  many  of  the  poor  depend  for  their  livelihoods.  In  particular,  ADB’s 
Strategy 2020 supports investment in essential public services, such as water and sanitation, as 
these investments support improvements in health, agriculture, and rural development, and 
provide  the  opportunity  for  all  to  improve  their  standards  of  living,  thereby  contributing  to 
economic  growth,  poverty  reduction,  and  mitigation  of  extreme  inequalities.    For  further 
information about the fund’s poverty reduction and social strategy, please refer to Apendix 3.     
 
2.  Consistency with the Country Strategy 
9.  The country partnership strategy (CPS) for the PRC, 2008–20106 seeks to address 
environmental sustainability through greater attention to the management of natural resources 
and ecosystems as a key priority for the PRC and ADB. This new emphasis will result in 
increased lending for natural resource management, agriculture, energy conservation and clean 
energy, and urban and rural development. The CPS also identifies water supply and sanitation 
as one of the priority sectors for development. This fund—with its emphasis on water and water 
infrastructure investments focusing on municipal, industrial, agricultural applications along with 
environmentally friendly water projects primarily targeting the PRC—aligns very well with the 
CPS.   
 
10.  ADB’s 10-year strategic framework for the Greater Mekong Subregion Program focuses 
on enhancing private sector participation in development and promoting sustainable use of the 
subregion’s  shared  natural  resources.  For  example,  through  selected  technical  assistance 
interventions,  ADB  is  augmenting  the  climate  change  mitigation  and  adaptation  efforts  of 
national  and  local  governments  in  Cambodia  and  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic 
(Lao PDR). ADB is conducting a study on flood risk vulnerability in five southern provinces of

the Lao PDR to design adaptation strategies and enhance the resilience of rice farmers and 
rural infrastructure. In Cambodia, ADB is cooperating with the World Bank to implement a ―pilot 
program for climate resilience‖ to mainstream climate risks in national and sectoral development 
planning and to support key adaptation interventions in the agriculture, water resources, and 
rural infrastructure sectors.7 The fund is consistent with this strategy and will contribute to 
improved rural infrastructure and water resources in Southeast Asia and the Greater Mekong 
Subregion.   
 
3.  Consistency with the Sector Strategy 
11.  In 2001, ADB outlined its vision for water management in the region in its ―Water for All‖ 
policy. The policy recognizes that, as a resource, water must be managed to meet needs 
without causing conflict or stressing natural resources. It also recognizes that innovative and 
cooperative financing efforts are crucial for the success of water projects. ADB, through its 
water  sector  programs,  provides  funding  for  the  development  and  upgrading  of  water 
infrastructure in Asia. ADB’s commitment to the water sector is illustrated in the Water Financing 
Program, 2006–2010, in which investments in water were expected to double and be directed 
toward  reforms  and capacity  development  programs  in rural  communities,  cities,  and river 
basins; and in the associated Water Financing Partnership Facility to mobilize cofinancing and 
investments from development partners.   
 
12.  As a large majority of the water utilities in Asia are publicly owned, working actively on 
public–private  partnerships  (PPPs)  is  crucial  to  accomplishing  water  sector  investment 
objectives. To that end, in April 2007, ADB made an equity investment in Asia Infrastructure 
Project Development (AIPD) together with three Singapore-based companies (Crest Spring,8 
Konzen  Group,9 and  United  Engineers).10   AIPD’s  mission  is  to  identify  and  incubate 
commercially viable PPP projects in water supply, sanitation, and wastewater treatment in the 
PRC. In so doing, AIPD aims to enhance private sector participation and to play a critical role in 
the delivery of services in the water sector.   
 
13.  As of the end of 2009, ADB had lent $25 billion for water-related projects. In February 
2010, ADB and Daiwa Securities Group announced the issuance of a water bond for financing 
water sector investments in Asia and the Pacific. According to ADB estimates, Asia needs 
$8 billion annually of capital investment to meet targets for safe drinking water in the next 
decade.

mainboard-listed group of companies with core strengths in engineering, construction, and integrated facility 
management.

4.  Lessons Learned from Previous Operations     
14.  The key recommendations of ADB’s 2005 evaluation study of the ―Water for All‖ policy 
were  (i) to  increase  ADB’s  commitments  and  develop  ADB’s  capacities  through  increased 
investments, staff realignment and development, and providing leadership in the region with 
respect to prioritizing the water sector; and (ii) to promote leveraging innovations to increase 
water access, affordability, efficiency, and cost-effectiveness, including nuanced guidance on 
subsidy use, promoting PPPs, alternative financing modalities under the Innovative Efficiency 
Initiative (IEI), robust operations and maintenance arrangements, and scaling up of alternative 
technologies.  The  fund’s  private  equity  investment  in  water  and  wastewater  assets  and 
utilization of PPPs such as AIPD emulate these goals.  
 
15.  Key recommendations of ADB’s evaluation study of private equity funds, in addition to a 
number  of  general  suggestions  (e.g.,  enhancing  staffing,  risk  management  systems,  and 
portfolio management), included (i) strengthening country programming arrangements so there 
is better coordination in the development of the nonbank financial sector, and (ii) articulating an 
operational strategy that sets out target countries and sectors. The fund generates synergies 
between public sector efforts in the various target countries and the private sector investments 
that will be made through the fund, and aligns with ADB’s focus on underinvested countries and 
sectors. 
 
5.  Consistency with Other Relevant ADB Operations 
16.  ADB recognizes that continued poverty reduction in Asia and the Pacific will not be 
possible without proactive efforts to mitigate the causes of global warming and to help the 
region adapt to the impacts of climate change. ADB recognizes the water and agriculture 
sectors as being most sensitive to climate change, as water is the principal medium through 
which  climate  change  is  manifested.11 Insofar  as  the  fund  seeks  to  invest  in  water  and 
wastewater assets, it is consistent with these and other climate change initiatives of ADB’s 
operation departments.   
 
17.  The fund is also consistent with a number of ADB’s region-wide strategic priority actions 
for furthering progress in ADB’s climate change program. One such action is to promote climate 
resilience. Many of the adverse impacts of climate change, such as reduced fresh water supply 
and spread of disease, are predicted to have gender-specific impacts. Adjusting to the need for 
climate-resilient  development  will  mean  building  responses  to  the  physical,  social,  and 
economic impacts of climate change into all aspects of development planning and investment.  
Since  water  is  the  principal  medium  through  which  climate  change  is  manifested,  special 
attention will be given to improving DMC capacities for climate-resilient water management in 
urban, rural, and river basin settings through investments such as those targeted by the fund.   
 
C.  Development Impact 
18.  Outputs and Outcome. The key outputs of ADB’s investment will be the establishment 
of the fund itself, as well as the fund’s investments in water and wastewater assets, ongoing 
management advice to investee projects, and profitable divestment from its investments. This 
will increase the flow of funds and expertise into water-related initiatives, expand and improve 
water infrastructure in targeted DMCs, and improve investee project financial performance and 
governance (outcome).

19.  Impact. The ultimate development impact of the proposed investment will be sustainable 
water sector development in ADB’s DMCs, as well as private sector development in the water 
and  environment  sectors.  Through  ADB’s  support  of  the  fund,  the  following  development 
impacts will also be achieved: 
 
(i)  The fund’s focused investments in clean water, sanitation, energy efficiency, and 
new  water-related  technology  will  address  the  increasing  issues  on  water 
pollution from domestic, industrial, and agricultural activities in the water sector in 
Asia.  These  investments  thus  help  in  achieving  effective  water  resource 
management that has inherent linkages to other development-related sectors 
such as food, energy, and the environment. 
 
(ii)  The money invested by the fund will lead to the portfolio companies’ growth and 
expansion.    Further,  the  fund’s  investments  in  greenfield  projects  under 
development will lead to developing individual companies in the private sector, 
creating jobs, and contributing to sustainable employment in the region.  
 
20.  Ancillary developmental benefits will include sustainable water supply and economic 
development, increased private sector participation and development, and mitigation of the 
effects of climate change. 
 
III.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY  
A.  Ownership 
21.  The  Asia  Water  Fund  will  be  incorporated  as  a  Cayman  Islands  exempted  limited 
partnership. AmAsia Water Management (GP) Ltd., an exempted company incorporated with 
limited liability under the laws of the Cayman Islands, will be the general partner of the fund.  
The  fund  manager,  AmAsia  Water  Management  Pte.  Ltd.,  is  a  private  limited  company 
incorporated  under  the  laws  of  Singapore  and  wholly  owned  by  MVMI,  a  wholly  owned 
subsidiary of AmInvestment Group, which is part of the AmBank Group.   
  
1.  AmInvestment Group  
 
22.  AmInvestment Group Berhad is one of Malaysia’s leading investment banking groups 
with over 30 years of experience. It offers a full range of retail, corporate, and investment 
banking  services.  It  also  provides  asset  management  services,  and  is  an  adviser  to  the 
Government of Malaysia with regard to formulating the Malaysian Privatization Master Plan, 
having a wide range of experience in privatizations and PPPs.   
 
23.  MVMI, a wholly owned subsidiary of AmInvestment Group, was incorporated in Malaysia 
in 1984. Since its inception, MVMI has managed three country funds: Malaysian Ventures I, 
Malaysian Ventures II, and AmPrivate Equity. MVMI also managed the SEAVI-Advent fund—the 
region’s first fund focused on venture capital and private equity investing in the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations—on behalf of Advent International.  
 
25.  The  continuity  of  MVMI’s  well  vetted  investment  processes  and  risk  management 
practices will benefit the fund, as will the involvement of two key team members with experience 
working together on prior MVMI funds. The value of the sponsor’s private equity platform, as 
well as the ability of its management team to execute the fund’s strategy, is demonstrated by 
the fund manager’s execution of a water sector investment in YC Foxin in the first quarter (Q) of 
2010  through  MVMI’s  AmPrivate  Equity  fund.  Through  this  investment,  the  sponsor  also 
established an extensive deal referral network among water sector developers and related

6       
 
government authorities in the PRC, making significant strides toward increasing the fund’s deal 
pipeline.     
 
B.  Governance Structure 
1.  Management  
26.  The  initial  investment  team  of the  fund manager  has  a good  mix  of  private  equity 
investment experience and water technology experience. Some of the key team members have 
worked together for many years on MVMI’s prior private equity funds and its current fund, 
AmPrivate Equity.  
 
2.  Corporate Governance 
27.  The fund manager will have an experienced board of directors, and the general partner 
of the fund will have an advisory board, comprising certain institutional investors, to represent 
the interests of the investors, supervise the fund’s operations, and advise and guide the fund 
manager. ADB will be represented on the advisory board.  
 
3.  Risk Management  
28.  The fund manager will manage risk through its investment process, which involves 
several  layers  of  approval,  and  through  its  investment  committee,  which  is  composed  of 
members with extensive experience in the water sector and investment management.  
   
 
 
C.  Business Overview and Strategy 
1.  Investment Objectives and Policies   
 
29.  The  fund  aims  to  provide  investors  with  stable,  long-term  capital  growth  and  cash 
distributions by investing in water and water-related assets in the PRC and Southeast Asia. The 
fund  will  seek  to  mitigate  investment  risk  through  portfolio  diversification  with  respect  to 
geographic regions as well as sector (e.g., municipal water, industrial water, agricultural water, 
etc.), contracting with reputable engineering parties, investing in companies with high corporate 
governance and financial management standards, and by seeking a majority ownership stake 
with the aim of having greater control and oversight of each portfolio investment. The fund will 
invest 70% of the portfolio in the PRC and the rest in Southeast Asia. No more than 10% of the 
commitments will be invested in a single transaction.     
 
  2.  Investment Strategy 
 
30.  The fund’s investment strategy will be to create a diversified portfolio of assets with 
opportunities for strong capital gains in the following water subsectors: 
(a)  municipal water and wastewater treatment plants, 
(b)  industrial water and wastewater treatment plants,  
(c)  rural water and wastewater treatment plants,  
(d)  agricultural wastewater treatment plants, and  
(e)  water rehabilitation projects;

7 
IV.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The ADB Assistance and Transaction Structure 
31.  ADB proposes to make an equity investment of up to $20 million in the fund or 25% of 
the fund’s total share capital, whichever is less. ADB will not be the single largest investor in the 
fund. The targeted fund size is $100 million, with a first closing of about $40 million. The fund 
has been well received by other development financial institutions such as IFC.  
 
B.  Justification for ADB Assistance 
32.  Catalytic and demonstration effect. Given the significant need for private investments 
in the water sector, ADB will have a catalytic role in attracting local and foreign private equity 
capital to help build water and water-related infrastructure in Asia. ADB’s intervention through 
this fund will (i) demonstrate a framework to other development financial institutions in terms of 
how to address the water shortage issue and how to support water sector development, and (ii) 
help  mobilize  capital  to  support  other  private  equity  funds  that  pursue  this  path.  ADB’s 
investment in the fund will help to develop fund managers and financial professionals with 
experience in the water infrastructure and services asset class in the region. 
 
33.  Private  sector  development.  The  fund  will  employ  market-based  mechanisms  to 
develop profitable and sustainable enterprises in the water sector, which needs it the most. 
ADB’s contribution to this type of initiative assists its DMCs to implement country-specific private 
sector development strategies. 
 
34.  Social and environmental issues. The transaction will have to comply with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Environment and Social Safeguards    
35.  ADB’s investment is classified category FI under the Safeguard Policy Statement. IFC 
has conducted environmental and social due diligence on the fund following its environmental 
and social review procedures. Based on IFC’s findings, the fund manager was informed that it 
should expect environment and safeguards (E&S) audits on municipal projects to be more 
lengthy than industrial projects (at least 6 months) and that the fund manager would be required 
to include E&S due diligence as a critical job specification of the water specialist that the fund is 
planning to hire. Furthermore, as a condition of IFC’s investment, the fund will adopt a social 
and environmental management system (SEMS). The fund will be required to establish and 
maintain  an  environmental  and  social  management  system  (ESMS)  as  part  of  its  overall 
management system to meet national laws and/or ADB requirements. The SEMS and/or ESMS 
will have to comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements on the environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. The SEMS and/or ESMS satisfactory to ADB 
will  be  adopted  by  the  fund  before  the  first  disbursement  for  the  purpose  of  financing  a 
subproject.  In  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  ADB’s  ESMS,  the  fund  will  appoint  an 
environmental  and  social  safeguard  manager  and  staff  to  implement  the  ESMS;  the  staff 
concerned  will  attend  ADB-approved  or  sponsored  training  related  to  compliance  and 
monitoring activities; and the proposed subprojects will be screened against the Prohibited 
Investment Activities List. An outline of an ESMS is in Appendix 2.

8       
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
36.  The fund was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) and 
policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism (2003). 
Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will 
require the fund manager and the sponsor to institute, maintain, and comply with internal 
procedures and controls following international best practice standards for preventing corruption 
or money laundering activities or the financing of terrorism and covenant with ADB to refrain 
from engaging in such activities. The investment documentation between ADB and the fund will 
further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings. 
 
37.  The general partner of the fund will be incorporated as an exempted company in the 
Cayman Islands, an offshore financial center and common location of incorporation for funds 
and general partners. Incorporation in an  offshore financial center allows the fund and its 
investors to avoid double taxation, as a result of the Cayman Islands’ own tax regulations and 
the tax treaties that it has with other countries. Having undertaken its own due diligence of this 
matter, the project team is satisfied that the fund will not be used for cross-border tax evasion, 
money laundering, or the financing of terrorism. 
 
C.  Assurances 
38.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter), 
the Government of the PRC will be requested to confirm it has no objection to the proposed 
assistance to the fund. Following the approval of the proposed investment by ADB’s Board of 
Directors, ADB will enter into suitable documentation with the fund and the fund manager, in 
form and substance satisfactory to ADB. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $20,000,000 in the Asia Water Fund from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President

2.  Financing arrangements 
 
2.1  Fund raises $40 million by first closing in Q2 2011, comprised of: the 
lower of $20 million or 20% from IFC; the lower of $20 million or 25% 
from ADB; $13 million from the fund manager; and the remainder from 
other investors.   
 
2.2  Fund raises an additional minimum of $20-30 million by final closing 
(within 12 months of the first close), for a total fund size of at least $60-
70 million,    
 
3.  Investment activities 
 
3.1  The fund promotes itself in the market and attracts attention from 
project sponsors on an ongoing basis (Q4 2010–Q4 2015). 
 
3.2  The fund evaluates these opportunities and selects projects for 
financing as appropriate (Q4 2010–Q4 2015). 
 
3.3  The fund adds value to investments over time (Q4 2010–Q4 2020). 
 
3,4  The fund seeks exit opportunities, such as strategic buyouts or 
preparing companies for initial public offerings, and achieves exits from 
investments (Q4 2016–Q4 2020). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, DMC = developing member country, EBITDA = earnings before interest, taxes, 
depreciation and amortization, IFC = International Finance Corporation, IRR = internal rate of return, MLD = million liters 
per day, PPP = public–private partnership, Q = quarter. 
Water infrastructure sector includes municipal and/or industrial water and wastewater treatment plants, agricultural 
wastewater treatment plants, and environment friendly water-related projects. 
a  Baseline targets are not included for private equity fund investments as the actual companies and sectors that the fund 
will invest in can not be confirmed until the end of the fund’s investment period. 
b  Fundraising is done by end of 2011; investment period by end of 2015; divestment period by end of 2020 plus optional 
two 1-year-extensions by  2022.
